The first season of the American [[Satire|satirical]] [[superhero]] television series ''[[The Boys (TV series)|The Boys]]'', the first series in the [[The Boys (franchise)|franchise]] based on the [[The Boys (comics)|comic book series of the same name]] written by [[Garth Ennis]] and [[Darick Robertson]], was developed for television by American writer and television producer [[Eric Kripke]]. The season was produced by [[Sony Pictures Television]] in association with [[Point Grey Pictures]], [[Original Film]], Kripke Enterprises, Kickstart Entertainment and KFL Nightsky Productions.

The show's first season stars [[Karl Urban]], [[Jack Quaid]], [[Antony Starr]], [[Erin Moriarty (actress)|Erin Moriarty]], [[Dominique McElligott]], [[Jessie T. Usher]], [[Laz Alonso]], [[Chace Crawford]], [[Tomer Kapon]], [[Karen Fukuhara]], [[Nathan Mitchell]], and [[Elisabeth Shue]]. The story takes place in a universe where most of the superpowered individuals are recognized as [[superhero]]es, but in reality abuse their powers for personal gain, information the public is kept unaware of. The series follows the eponymous Boys, led by [[Billy Butcher]] (Urban), a group of vigilantes looking to bring down Vought International and expose its corrupt superheroes. When his girlfriend is accidentally killed by [[List of The Boys characters#A-Train|A-Train]] (Usher), [[Hughie Campbell]] (Quaid) joins the Boys to get revenge against the Seven. Meanwhile, [[Starlight (character)|Annie January]] (Moriarty) is forced to face the truth about those she admires, after she joins the Seven, led by [[Homelander]] (Starr). The Boys attempt to stop Vought from receiving government support for superheroes by uncovering the company's secrets. When Hughie and Annie begin a romantic relationship, the conflict is muddled despite the two of them initially being unaware of each other's affiliations.

The season premiered on the streaming service [[Amazon Prime Video]] on July 26, 2019, with all the eight episodes being released in a single day. It became the most watched series released by Prime Video at the time of its release, having managed to attract a wide audience that led to a high viewership. The season received largely positive reviews from critics and audiences, with high praise towards its social commentary, story, black humor, faithfulness to the source material, visual style, screenplay, and performances (particularly Urban, Quaid, and Starr). The series was renewed for a [[The Boys season 2|second season]] on July 19, 2019.<ref name=":18">{{Cite web|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=July 19, 2019|title='The Boys' Renewed For Season 2 By Amazon; Aya Cash Closes Deal As Stormfront|url=https://deadline.com/2019/07/the-boys-renewed-season-2-amazon-aya-cash-closes-deal-stormfront-1202649409/|access-date=June 13, 2021|website=[[Deadline Hollywood|Deadline]]|archive-date=July 19, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190719235155/https://deadline.com/2019/07/the-boys-renewed-season-2-amazon-aya-cash-closes-deal-stormfront-1202649409/|url-status=live}}</ref>

==Episodes==
<onlyinclude>{{Episode table |background=#380000 |overall=5 |season=5 |title=32 |director=13 |writer=27 |airdate=18 |released=y |episodes=
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 1
| EpisodeNumber2  = 1
| Title           = [[The Name of the Game (The Boys episode)|The Name of the Game]]
| DirectedBy      = [[Dan Trachtenberg]]
| WrittenBy       = [[Eric Kripke]]
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the original comic books|The Name of the Game (comic book){{!}}The Name of the Game (2006 comic book)|The Bloody Doors Off#The Name of the Game{{!}}The Name of the Game (2012 comic book)}}[[Hughie Campbell|Hugh "Hughie" Campbell]] suffers [[posttraumatic stress disorder|mental trauma]] after his girlfriend Robin is accidentally killed by celebrity superhero A-Train. Lawyers offer a $45,000 [[Settlement (litigation)|settlement]], which Hughie hesitates to accept. Aspiring superhero [[Annie January]] auditions as "Starlight" and is accepted to join the superhero group the Seven following the [[Lamplighter (comics)|Lamplighter]]'s retirement. Arriving at the Seven's headquarters, she is greeted by [[List of The Boys characters#The Deep|The Deep]], who [[blackmail]]s her into performing [[oral sex]] on him.<ref name="Comicsverse Deep-Starlight">{{cite news|date=July 23, 2019|first=Nicole|last=Herviou|url=https://comicsverse.com/complicated-role-sexual-violence-in-the-boys|title=The Complicated Role of Sexual Violence in THE BOYS|publisher=ComicsVerse|access-date=July 29, 2019|archive-date=December 27, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211227123423/https://comicsverse.com/complicated-role-sexual-violence-in-the-boys/|url-status=live}}</ref> Vigilante [[Billy Butcher]] offers Hughie a chance to expose superhero corruption, taking him to a secret "Supes Club" to show him security footage of A-Train laughing about Robin's death. Butcher asks Hughie to take the settlement money and secretly place a [[covert listening device|bug]] at Seven Tower, but Hughie initially refuses. In Central Park, Annie meets Hughie by happenstance, motivating each other to stand up for themselves and face their challenges. Hughie plants the bug, but Translucent discovers it and confronts him. Butcher arrives and helps Hughie incapacitate Translucent. Elsewhere, [[Homelander]] destroys the Mayor of Baltimore's plane while in flight, killing all passengers, in response to the Mayor's attempt to blackmail his boss at Vought International: company VP [[The Guy From Vought|Madelyn Stillwell]].
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 2
| EpisodeNumber2  = 2
| Title           = [[Cherry (The Boys episode)|Cherry]]
| DirectedBy      = [[Matt Shakman]]
| WrittenBy       = Eric Kripke
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the original comic book volume|The Name of the Game (comic book)#Cherry{{!}}Cherry (comic book)}}Butcher and Hughie take Translucent to former partner Frenchie, who makes a meta-bullet to pierce the hero's diamond-hard skin, but it fails to kill him. Butcher turns to [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] Dept. Director Susan Raynor for the "Mallory files", but she refuses. Stillwell tells Homelander about evidence the Deep found incriminating him for the plane crash, so she handles it while he talks to Deep. While working with the Deep, Annie promises to kill him if he tries to sexually assault her again. Stillwell uses shapeshifting Supe Doppelg√§nger to blackmail Senator Calhoun into allowing a vote that could enable Vought to contract superheroes to the military. Annie stops an attempted rape, unaware she is being recorded. Her agent, Ashley Barrett, reprimands her for potentially causing negative exposure and legal implications. While Homelander searches for Translucent, Frenchie places [[C-4 (explosive)|C-4]] explosives in Translucent's colon, who fearfully confesses A-Train was with his girlfriend Popclaw before he killed Robin. The Boys learn Homelander is nearby, so they cannot risk killing Translucent with the C-4. While Frenchie and Butcher create a distraction elsewhere, Translucent escapes and convinces Hughie to let him go. However, Hughie changes his mind and detonates the C-4, killing Translucent.
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 3
| EpisodeNumber2  = 3
| Title           = [[Get Some (The Boys episode)|Get Some]]
| DirectedBy      = [[Philip Sgriccia|Phil Sgriccia]]
| WrittenBy       = [[George Mastras]]
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the original comic book volume|Get Some (comic book)}}Hughie moves out after telling his father how he truly feels. Annie gains positive publicity for stopping the rape but subsequently learns Stillwell wants her to wear a revealing costume. She declines, but Stillwell forces her to do so lest she lose her job. Butcher brings in his former friend, [[Mother's Milk (character)|Mother's Milk]] (M.M.), to run surveillance on Popclaw and has Hughie install [[spyware]] on her computer, through which they learn that A-Train takes a [[performance-enhancing substance|drug]] called Compound V. Butcher wants to expose them before Supes can be allowed into the [[United States Armed Forces]], but requires a vial of Compound V from A-Train's upcoming race with another speedster, Shockwave. Beforehand, Hughie meets Annie and invites her to lunch, where they open up to each other. Meanwhile, A-Train secretly uses Compound V to win and publicly announces he is single, breaking his promise to Popclaw to announce their relationship. With M.M. deducing Popclaw stole some vials, the Boys find her heartbroken, [[Substance intoxication|high]], and in the midst of accidentally killing her landlord during hyper-charged sex. Butcher uses this to blackmail her as an informant. At Vought headquarters, Homelander presents Translucent's remains to Stillwell along with Butcher's message "COMING FOR YOU".
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 4
| EpisodeNumber2  = 4
| Title           = [[The Female of the Species (The Boys episode)|The Female of the Species]]
| DirectedBy      = [[Frederick E.O. Toye|Fred Toye]]
| WrittenBy       = [[Craig Rosenberg]]
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the character|The Female (The Boys character){{!}}The Female (of the Species)}}Following Popclaw's tip, the Boys find a [[Triad (organized crime)|Triad]] hideout holding an imprisoned Japanese woman they call "the Female". After Frenchie frees her, she kills her guards and escapes. While M.M. finds evidence that she was a test subject, Hughie goes bowling with Annie, bugging her phone at Butcher's request. With their Compound V supply compromised, A-Train has Popclaw go into hiding while he searches for the Female. Stillwell sends Homelander and Queen Maeve to save a hijacked airliner. After Homelander accidentally destroys the control panel, he abandons the plane and its passengers, forcing Maeve to leave with him before she can rescue them. After the Female kills a woman associated with her captors, Frenchie tracks her to [[Pennsylvania Station (New York City)|Penn Station]] and makes a momentary connection with her before losing her in the crowd just as A-Train arrives and tries to kill her. Frenchie attracts a crowd to distract A-Train, allowing the Female to escape. The Boys corner her, but she attacks them before Butcher uses [[knockout gas]]. Stillwell is pleased to see Homelander use the airliner tragedy to push for [[militarization|militarized]] Supes while Maeve grieves for those she and Homelander allowed to die.
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 5
| EpisodeNumber2  = 5
| Title           = [[Good for the Soul (The Boys episode)|Good for the Soul]]
| DirectedBy      = [[Stefan Schwartz]]
| WrittenBy       = [[Anne Cofell Saunders]]
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the original comic book volume|Good for the Soul (comic book)}}At the Believe Expo, Annie is quietly directed to push Vought's agenda while Butcher has Hughie use her to meet Ezekiel, the Expo host and their next lead. Feeling guilty for letting the airliner crash, Maeve visits her ex-girlfriend Elena, but leaves before explaining herself fully. Butcher talks with his sister-in-law, Rachel, over putting a tombstone to his wife [[Becky Saunders|Becca]]. After A-Train kills Popclaw for betraying him, he returns to her apartment and finds surveillance footage of Frenchie. Once Ezekiel is alone, Hughie extorts him for information about Compound V while Homelander rallies the expo's crowd with an impromptu hardline speech. Annie breaks script to speak candidly on Christianity, her sexual assault, and the compromises she made for her corporate employer. Hughie later sympathizes with her, telling her about Robin's death and its toll on him. In a hospital, Butcher and M.M. discover Vought is using Compound V on infants to manufacture Supes years in advance. Frenchie discovers [[Black Noir|Black Noir]] is looking for him. While attempting to escape, he is told to leave the Female behind but releases her out of sympathy. She seemingly dies protecting him from Noir, but her wounds immediately heal.
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 6
| EpisodeNumber2  = 6
| Title           = [[The Innocents (The Boys episode)|The Innocents]]
| DirectedBy      = [[Jennifer Phang]]
| WrittenBy       = Rebecca Sonnenshine
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the original comic book volume|The Innocents (comic book)}}Now informed, the Boys know Vought has used super charities to smuggle Compound V disguised as vaccines and make super-babies since 1971. With Ashley fired, Stillwell demands Annie comply with her designed image, but she refuses, remarking that firing her after reporting a sexual assault would hurt Vought's image. Aware it was the Deep, Stillwell has him publicly apologize and transfers him to [[Sandusky, Ohio]] for a "[[sabbatical]]". Butcher brings Hughie to a superhuman survivors' support group but leaves after yelling at them for doing nothing to get justice. Butcher later tells Hughie that Homelander raped his wife, who went missing shortly afterward. Frenchie and M.M. get help from [[telepath]] Mesmer to see into the Female's mind, learning her name is Kimiko and that she was kidnapped by the Shining Light Liberation Army terrorist group. They also learn that Vought is making Compound V-boosted terrorists to push their agenda for militarizing Supes. Butcher tells Raynor, but he calls off the deal when she refuses to target Homelander. Mesmer gives Homelander surveillance photos of the Boys. Butcher finds out about Hughie and Annie, warning him not to fraternize with the enemy and threatening to tell her about Translucent.
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 7
| EpisodeNumber2  = 7
| Title           = [[The Self-Preservation Society (The Boys episode)|The Self-Preservation Society]]
| DirectedBy      = [[Dan Attias]]
| WrittenBy       = Craig Rosenberg & Ellie Monahan
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the original comic book volume|The Self-Preservation Society}}Hughie and Annie have sex at a hotel, unaware Butcher has followed them. A depressed Deep finds his transfer dull and is sexually assaulted by a fangirl. Holding a meeting discussing Hughie killing Translucent, extorting Ezekiel, and A-Train killing Robin, Homelander accuses Starlight of co-conspiracy, but Maeve defends her. When A-Train calls Hughie, claiming he is holding his dad hostage, the Boys deduce Mesmer betrayed them, for which Butcher later murders him. Hughie obtains Compound V to distract A-Train and allow Kimiko to cripple him. Homelander asks Vought scientist Dr. Jonah Vogelbaum about Becca, who informs him she was pregnant with his child before claiming they both died and Vought covered it up. Questioning the revelation's timing, Vogelbaum regrets raising him in a lab, calling Homelander his "greatest failure". Butcher asks Raynor to protect Hughie and M.M.'s families in exchange for evidence. As Raynor charges Stillwell and Vought, she learns of the superhuman terrorist "Naqib". Annie confronts Hughie, who explains Vought's use of Compound V before Butcher arrives to [[Extraction (military)|exfil]] him and shoots her.
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
{{Episode list/sublist|The Boys season 1
| EpisodeNumber   = 8
| EpisodeNumber2  = 8
| Title           = [[You Found Me (The Boys episode)|You Found Me]]
| DirectedBy      = Eric Kripke
| WrittenBy       = Anne Cofell Saunders & Rebecca Sonnenshine
| OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2019|7|26}}
| ShortSummary    = {{For|the original comic book chapter|The Bloody Doors Off#You Found Me{{!}}You Found Me (comic book)}}[[The Pentagon]] classifies Compound V as a [[controlled substance]] and the Boys as fugitives while Annie confronts her mother. Angry at being racially profiled while out of costume, an injured A-Train relapses with Compound V. Butcher takes Hughie to Colonel Grace Mallory, his former supervisor. She refuses participation, but informs them about Homelander's connection to Stillwell and warns Hughie about Butcher's desire for vengeance. The Deep learns Stillwell has denied his return to the Seven and suffers an emotional breakdown. Hughie asks for Annie's help, but she refuses out of distrust. After seeing her old self reflected in her, Maeve opens up to Annie. Homelander confesses to Stillwell that he secretly made the super-terrorists and they have sex. At a [[black site]], Hughie helps Frenchie and M.M. free Kimiko following their capture before Annie rescues them. A-Train arrives and fights Annie until he suffers a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] and goes into [[cardiac arrest]]. Hughie applies [[CPR]], but Annie takes over so he can escape. Butcher takes Stillwell hostage and fits her with explosives to bait Homelander, who kills Stillwell himself. Butcher detonates the explosives, but Homelander saves him, revealing [[Becky Saunders|Becca]] was hidden away to raise Homelander's son.
| LineColor       = 380000
}}
}}</onlyinclude>

===Cameos===

==Production==
{{hatnote|Additional production information and episode-specific content can be found at each episode's article.}}

===Development===
On April 6, 2016, it was announced that a television adaptation for the [[Garth Ennis]] comic book series ''[[The Boys (comics)|The Boys]]'' was in active development by [[Cinemax]], after the original plans for a film adaptation were abandoned due to creative differences between the studios and the creative department behind the film.<ref name=":20">{{Cite web |last=Writer |first=Guest |date=2012-02-13 |title=The Boys Movie No Longer In Development At Columbia |url=https://whatculture.com/film/the-boys-movie-no-longer-in-development-at-columbia |access-date=2023-12-14 |website=[[WhatCulture]] |language=en |archive-date=December 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214190913/https://whatculture.com/film/the-boys-movie-no-longer-in-development-at-columbia |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=":19">{{Cite web |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |date=2016-04-06 |title=‚ÄòThe Boys‚Äô Drama Based On Comic Book Set At Cinemax With Seth Rogen, Evan Goldberg, Eric Kripke, Original Film & Sony |url=https://deadline.com/2016/04/the-boys-drama-series-comic-book-cinemax-seth-rogen-evan-goldberg-eric-kripke-original-film-sony-1201732097/ |access-date=2023-12-14 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood|Deadline]] |language=en-US |archive-date=February 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180219035113/http://deadline.com/2016/04/the-boys-drama-series-comic-book-cinemax-seth-rogen-evan-goldberg-eric-kripke-original-film-sony-1201732097/ |url-status=live }}</ref> While they were working for the series [[Preacher (TV series)|''Preacher'']] which is also based on a comic book series written by Ennis, [[Evan Goldberg]], and [[Seth Rogen]] were approached and then recruited to work for the series as the executive producers and directors for the pilot episode.<ref name=":19" /> [[Eric Kripke]] who is a longtime fan of Ennis work was angered over not being approached to work for the television adaptation of ''Preacher'', something that he reclaimed to Rogen and Golberg during a meeting with them. When the duo told him about the project, Kripke accepted to become involved and was eventually hired as the showrunner and head writer of the series.<ref name=":21">{{Cite web |last=Radish |first=Christina |date=2019-07-26 |title=Eric Kripke on Amazon's The Boys and the End of Supernatural |url=https://collider.com/the-boys-eric-kripke-interview/ |access-date=2023-12-14 |website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |language=en |archive-date=March 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230314204513/https://collider.com/the-boys-eric-kripke-interview/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The confirmed production companies to be involved with the series were [[Point Grey Pictures]], [[Original Film]], and [[Sony Pictures Television]].<ref name="Cinemax">{{cite web |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |date=April 6, 2016 |title='The Boys' Drama Based On Comic Book Set At Cinemax With Seth Rogen, Evan Goldberg, Eric Kripke, Original Film & Sony |url=https://deadline.com/2016/04/the-boys-drama-series-comic-book-cinemax-seth-rogen-evan-goldberg-eric-kripke-original-film-sony-1201732097/ |access-date=March 11, 2018 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |archive-date=February 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180219035113/http://deadline.com/2016/04/the-boys-drama-series-comic-book-cinemax-seth-rogen-evan-goldberg-eric-kripke-original-film-sony-1201732097/ |url-status=live }}</ref> 

However, the production costs for the series exceeded expectations, leading Cinemax to deem it too costly to proceed. Rather than cancel the series or seek a new creative team, Rogen, Goldberg, and Kripke were granted permission to find a new distributor.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Scott |first=Ryan |date=2021-12-20 |title=The Reason Cinemax Dropped The Boys |url=https://www.slashfilm.com/712973/the-reason-cinemax-dropped-the-boys/ |access-date=2023-12-14 |website=SlashFilm |language=en-US |archive-date=December 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214194610/https://www.slashfilm.com/712973/the-reason-cinemax-dropped-the-boys/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Selcke |first=Dan |date=2022-01-03 |title=Why The Boys didn't go forward at Cinemax |url=https://winteriscoming.net/2022/01/03/why-the-boys-did-not-go-forward-cinemax/ |access-date=2023-12-14 |website=Winter is Coming |language=en-US |archive-date=December 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214201234/https://winteriscoming.net/2022/01/03/why-the-boys-did-not-go-forward-cinemax/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In November 2017, Amazon acquired the rights to adapt "The Boys" into a television series, aiming to create a hit genre drama and broaden its audience. That same month, Amazon announced that the first season would consist of eight episodes, each costing over $11.2 million,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mallik |first=Esita |date=December 9, 2023 |title=‚ÄòThe Boys‚Äô Episodes‚Äô Estimated Budget Revealed: Before Season 4's Release Check Out The Alleged Cost Of Creating The Karl Urban-Led Series! |url=https://www.koimoi.com/television/the-boys-episodes-estimated-budget-revealed-before-season-4s-release-check-out-the-alleged-cost-of-creating-the-karl-urban-led-series |access-date=December 13, 2023 |website=Koimoi |archive-date=December 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231210205623/https://www.koimoi.com/television/the-boys-episodes-estimated-budget-revealed-before-season-4s-release-check-out-the-alleged-cost-of-creating-the-karl-urban-led-series/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Nunn |first=Christina |date=2022-11-06 |title='The Boys' Episodes Cost More Than $11 Million Each, Allowing For Bigger Action Sequences Every Season ===Writing===
''The Boys'' takes place in a universe where the superheroes are interpreted as corrupt celebrities who abuse their powers. Kripke wanted to explore how these heroes would be portrayed in real life, leading to several discussions of how to deconstruct the old myth of superheroes. He has admitted to being a fan of [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]], but believes that the old superhero myth portrayed in the comics and films would not happen in the real world as he considers that the people are selfish, believing that a person won't do something noble once it suddenly gains superpowers.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web |last=Clark |first=Travis |title=How Amazon's new superhero TV show, 'The Boys,' was shaped by Trump, Me Too, and 'sweet, sweet Bezos money' |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/the-boys-showrunner-eric-kripke-interview-trump-me-too-amazon-2019-7 |access-date=April 20, 2022 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417074343/https://www.businessinsider.com/the-boys-showrunner-eric-kripke-interview-trump-me-too-amazon-2019-7 |url-status=live }}</ref> As a long time fan of [[Garth Ennis]], Kripke began to read and follow the artist's work during his college years including the comic book series ''The Boys''. However he didn't intend to write the series exactly as the comics, feeling that it would be disastrous, leading him to make some changes to the series. The writers agreed that they needed to adjust the characters to fit the story, so long as they were complex and recognizable. In order to balance the show's satire and superhero tropes, Kripke explained: "We let any comedy or absurdity emerge out of the natural contradictions of putting a fantasy element in the real world. And so when those people have to take shits and go get tacos, it just gets funny."<ref name=":16">{{Cite web |last=Yeoman |first=Kevin |date=July 24, 2019 |title=Interview: Erick Kripke On Amazon's The Boys |url=https://screenrant.com/the-boys-interview-eric-kripke-comic-series-amazon/ |access-date=April 17, 2022 |website=ScreenRant |language=en-US |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417074340/https://screenrant.com/the-boys-interview-eric-kripke-comic-series-amazon/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

As the comic-book series portrays many of the key events from the storyline in a very graphic way, Kripke realized that many of them would be hard to adapt due to the [[Me Too movement|MeToo movement]]. However he understood that it was important to adapt some of them as like what on the comics did, the series would be pushing the boundaries, for which he dedided to adapt controversial scenes that would be relevant for the show while the others that weren't would not be adapted.<ref name=":18" /> Kripke considered that for the series it would be important to create a similar world that would the society that lives during these days, for which he decided to adapt the superheroes by combining the worst of the celebrities and politicians something that he considered to be a crazy idea that would show "how f‚Äîed we would all, as regular people, be" with such a combination.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Taylor |first=Elizabeth |date=2019-04-30 |title=Why 'The Boys' Will Tackle #MeToo and Trump |url=https://variety.com/2019/tv/news/the-boys-eric-kripke-tribeca-film-festival-politics-celebrity-1203200863/ |access-date=2023-07-03 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |language=en-US |archive-date=July 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230703233037/https://variety.com/2019/tv/news/the-boys-eric-kripke-tribeca-film-festival-politics-celebrity-1203200863/ |url-status=live }}</ref> As the season deals with [[corruption]] and the [[abuse of power]] that several superheroes commit as the story progresses, the writers were given the freedom to adapt the series faithfully to the comics as they considered that it was the only way to properly adapt the story they were trying to tell. Ennis admitted that he knew that the series would take a different direction from the comics as Kripke had different intentions over how to adapt the storyline, though he considers that the latter was the right guy to take the comic's complex themes to the small screen.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bentley |first=Rick |date=July 29, 2019 |title='The Boys' examines power, corruption |url=https://www.telegram.com/story/entertainment/2019/07/29/the-boys-examines-how-with-great-power-comes-great-corruption/4532033007/ |access-date=2023-07-03 |website=Telegram & Gazette |language=en-US |archive-date=July 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230703233035/https://www.telegram.com/story/entertainment/2019/07/29/the-boys-examines-how-with-great-power-comes-great-corruption/4532033007/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The season also develops the relationship between Hughie and Annie and its progress as the series progresses. Kripke considered to adapt this right as he sees the romantic relationship of the characters to be the emtional core to ensure that the viewers begin to care and worry about the characters and to show how much heart the series was given.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Salkowitz |first=Rob |date=July 19, 2019 |title='The Boys,' Amazon's Savage New Superhero Satire, Is 'The Most Topical Show On TV,' Says Showrunner |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robsalkowitz/2019/07/19/the-boys-amazons-savage-new-superhero-satire-is-the-most-topical-show-on-tv-says-showrunner/ |access-date=2023-07-03 |website=[[Forbes]] |language=en |archive-date=July 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230703233035/https://www.forbes.com/sites/robsalkowitz/2019/07/19/the-boys-amazons-savage-new-superhero-satire-is-the-most-topical-show-on-tv-says-showrunner/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

The season does not fully follow the storyline from the comics despite its faithfulness to the comic book series, as Kripke maintained the writers disciplined with the intention of retaining the show with a sense of reality by saying: "Anything that comes out of this drug is viable, and anything that doesn't we're not allowed to do".<ref name="Romano">{{cite magazine |last=Romano |first=Nick |title='The Boys' showrunner unpacks THAT cliffhanger, surprise cameos, and season 2 plans |url=https://ew.com/tv/2019/07/30/the-boys-season-1-ending-cameos-season-2/ |magazine=Entertainment Weekly |quote=Kripke wanted to also avoid 'fridging,' which sees women being killed off as motivation for male heroes. |access-date=March 24, 2022 |archive-date=June 1, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220601050921/https://ew.com/tv/2019/07/30/the-boys-season-1-ending-cameos-season-2/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=McGuire |first=Liam |date=September 22, 2020 |title=The Boys Version Of Martian Manhunter Was Too Unbelievable For The Show |url=https://screenrant.com/the-boys-martian-manhunter-jack-jupiter/ |access-date=April 20, 2022 |website=ScreenRant |language=en-US |archive-date=April 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220420172123/https://screenrant.com/the-boys-martian-manhunter-jack-jupiter/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In order to keep the realism that he wanted to capture for the series, Kripke decided to replace some of the characters of the comics that he considered to fantastical to be adapted with new characters exclusively created for the series, though keeping their personalities and powers from the comics.<ref name=":17">{{Cite web |last=De los Trinos |first=Angelo |date=July 30, 2019 |title=The Boys: 16 Differences Between The Comics And The Show |url=https://screenrant.com/boys-differences-between-comics-tv-show-amazon/ |access-date=April 20, 2022 |website=ScreenRant |language=en-US |archive-date=April 18, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220418203644/https://screenrant.com/boys-differences-between-comics-tv-show-amazon/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Rougeau |first=Michael |title=The Boys Season 2: Show Characters Compared With The Comics |url=https://www.gamespot.com/gallery/the-boys-season-2-show-characters-compared-with-the-comics/2900-3562/#20 |access-date=April 20, 2022 |website=GameSpot |language=en-US |archive-date=April 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220420172123/https://www.gamespot.com/gallery/the-boys-season-2-show-characters-compared-with-the-comics/2900-3562/#20 |url-status=live }}</ref> However, these changes weren't only made to keep the realism of the series as Kripke revealed that the changes were also to adapt series in the modern times. This change was done as Kripke considered that the original material from the comics would not be possible to adapt it to the series, due to the comics taking place in the 2000s with the first comic of ''The Boys'' being launched in 2006 stating: "There's been more than one situation where we've come up with a scene or storyline in the writer's room and then something happened in reality that was crazier than the story we were pitching. So, we've had to erase stories ‚Äôcause reality outdid us in how insane things are."<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Romano |first=Nick |title=Superheroes gone wild! 'Supernatural' creator previews 'The Boys,' his super-R-rated new show |url=https://ew.com/tv/2019/05/24/the-boys-eric-kripke-celebrity-politics/ |access-date=2023-07-06 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |language=en |archive-date=November 23, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231123121600/https://ew.com/tv/2019/05/24/the-boys-eric-kripke-celebrity-politics/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

===Filming===
Despite the series taking place in [[New York City]] like in the comics, it would be filmed in [[Toronto|Toronto, Canada]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Watson |first=Fay |date=July 26, 2019 |title=The Boys on Amazon location: Where is The Boys filmed? Where's it set? |url=https://www.express.co.uk/showbiz/tv-radio/1157369/The-Boys-Amazon-Prime-location-Where-is-The-Boys-filmed-Where-is-it-set-series |access-date=April 21, 2022 |website=Express |archive-date=April 21, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220421193333/https://www.express.co.uk/showbiz/tv-radio/1157369/The-Boys-Amazon-Prime-location-Where-is-The-Boys-filmed-Where-is-it-set-series |url-status=live }}</ref> Kripke revealed that the show was intended to begin its filming on the spring of 2018 to release in the following year. The filming for the first season officially began on May 22, 2018, in Toronto, with the production for the season expected to end on September 25, 2018.<ref name="SeriesOrder" /><ref name="Trachtenberg" /><ref>{{cite web |title=In Production: Toronto and Ontario |url=http://www.whatsfilming.ca/inproduction-toronto-ontario/ |website=What's Filming? |date=February 9, 2018 |access-date=July 16, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180717013139/http://www.whatsfilming.ca/inproduction-toronto-ontario/ |archive-date=July 17, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Moon |first=Ra |title=Where was The Boys Filmed? Guide to ALL the Filming Locations |url=https://www.atlasofwonders.com/2019/07/the-boys-filming-locations-toronto.html |access-date=June 11, 2021 |website=Atlas of Wonders |archive-date=June 12, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210612022204/https://www.atlasofwonders.com/2019/07/the-boys-filming-locations-toronto.html |url-status=live }}</ref> While the prIncipal photography for the series took place in Toronto, it was also confirmed that the show would be partially filmed at the cities of [[Mississauga]] and [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]] in a few locations which include the Central Parkway Mall, the Streetsville Gas Station, [[Tim Hortons Field]] stadium, and the Fallsview Residence.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Shinuda|first=Jonah|date=November 8, 2020|title=Did you know Prime's biggest TV series "The Boys" was partially filmed in Mississauga?|url=https://www.insauga.com/did-you-know-primes-biggest-tv-series-the-boys-was-partially-filmed-in-mississauga|access-date=June 11, 2021|website=Insauga|archive-date=June 12, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210612022200/https://www.insauga.com/did-you-know-primes-biggest-tv-series-the-boys-was-partially-filmed-in-mississauga|url-status=live}}</ref>

The crew filmed at several touristic locations from the city of Toronto such as the [[Roy Thomson Hall]], the [[Yonge‚ÄìDundas Square]], [[Lower Bay station|Lower Bay Station]], and the [[Sherbourne Common]]. In order to make it look like New York City and create the fictional places of the series such as the Seven Tower intending to capture the series universe, several of these locations were digitally altered through [[Visual effects|CGI]] including the interiors of several buildings, with several rooms being digitally altered and extended.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=The Boys filming locations in Canada |url=http://filipinosincanada.com/2020/09/04/the-boys-filming-locations/ |access-date=June 11, 2021 |archive-date=June 12, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210612042059/https://filipinosincanada.com/2020/09/04/the-boys-filming-locations/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> One of the series cinematographers Dan Stoloff revealed that as the series was set to portray the dark side of the characters such as greed, jealousy and pride, it was important to create a dark atmosphere and the colors that reflect the universe that was created. During the filming, Stoloff revealed that Kripke gave the crew a sense of ownership in order to freely develop the series ideas during the production, allowing the VFX crew to test and figure out how the production would be given in order to combine the visual effects and lighting prior to the shooting.<ref>{{Cite web |last= |date=2020-11-01 |title=Dan Stoloff Exclusive Interview on His Career, The Boys & Upcoming Projects |url=https://themovieculture.com/dan-stoloff-exclusive-interview-on-his-career-the-boys-and-upcoming-projects/ |access-date=2023-07-06 |website=The Movie Culture |language=en-US |archive-date=July 7, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230707162556/https://themovieculture.com/dan-stoloff-exclusive-interview-on-his-career-the-boys-and-upcoming-projects/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Filming for the first season [[Wrap (filmmaking)|wrapped]] on October 11, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Flook |first=Ray |date=October 17, 2018 |title=As The Boys Wraps Season 1 Filming, Did Karl Urban Confirm Season 2? |url=https://bleedingcool.com/comics/recent-updates/boys-season-1-filming-wraps-season-2/ |access-date=April 21, 2022 |website=Bleeding Cool |archive-date=April 21, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220421202455/https://bleedingcool.com/comics/recent-updates/boys-season-1-filming-wraps-season-2/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== Visual effects ===
The visual effects were provided by DNEG TV, [[Framestore]], Folks VFX, Mavericks VFX, [[Method Studios]], Monsters Aliens Robots Zombies VFX, Mr. X, [[Pixomondo]], Rocket Science VFX, [[Rodeo FX]], and Soho VFX, creating over 1400 visual effects shots for the season which for the crew took over five months to complete.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Frei |first=Vincent |date=2019-07-24 |title=THE BOYS |url=https://www.artofvfx.com/the-boys/ |access-date=2023-07-07 |website=The Art of VFX |language= |archive-date=January 10, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161623/https://www.artofvfx.com/the-boys/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The creation for the visual effects for the season were overseen by visual effects supervisor Stephan Fleet.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Boys |url=https://www.dneg.com/show/the-boys/ |access-date=2023-07-07 |website=DNEG |language=en-US |archive-date=July 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230710025224/https://www.dneg.com/show/the-boys/ |url-status=live }}</ref> While working in the production to adapt the blood and gore from the comics to the series, Fleet revealed that the crew decided to reduce a little amount of blood from the comics, as they wanted to the realism of those scenes for the series, following discussions of how to interpret the comics in a different medium. The crew mostly used practical fake blood for the series most violent moments, though they also used CGI for the creation of the some of them due to their complexity of shooting by using the practical ones as a reference.<ref>{{Cite web |last= |date=2020-05-05 |title=Balancing Blood and Believability in Superhero Twister THE BOYS |url=https://www.vfxvoice.com/balancing-blood-and-believability-in-superhero-twister-the-boys/ |access-date=2023-07-07 |website=VFX Voice |language=en-US |archive-date=January 22, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210122223512/https://www.vfxvoice.com/balancing-blood-and-believability-in-superhero-twister-the-boys/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Frei |first=Vincent |date=2019-08-27 |title=THE BOYS: Stephan Fleet - Overall VFX Supervisor |url=https://www.artofvfx.com/the-boys-stephan-fleet-overall-vfx-supervisor/ |access-date=2023-07-07 |website=The Art of VFX |language=en |archive-date=July 2, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230702071252/https://www.artofvfx.com/the-boys-stephan-fleet-overall-vfx-supervisor/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

Having already worked in several superhero movies, one of the series visual effects company Framestore was hired to develop several of the fight sequences for the series with several fight sequences with VFX supervisor Pedro Sabrosa stating "While they are about superheroes, Ennis and Robertson's graphic novels are much more grounded in reality than the high-concept superheroes we're used to seeing adapted for the big screen. With that in mind, we wanted our effects to reflect that by being more believable and having a certain level of realism to them. The big challenge in this sequence was adding CG elements to live action footage shot at a high frame rate because you don't have anywhere to hide; our work needed to be flawless."<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-08-22 |title=The Boys |url=https://www.framestore.com/work/The-boys-amazon?language=en |access-date=2023-07-10 |website=Framestore |archive-date=July 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230710032800/https://www.framestore.com/work/The-boys-amazon?language=en |url-status=live }}</ref> Framestore was in charge of creating the pilot's opening scene was indeed the last scene to be filmed and edited, with one of the visual effects supervisors stating that "We came into the process relatively late on and found out they wanted to do the opening sequence, which was‚Ä¶ um, you know, no pressure there! Interestingly, they shot that late: I think it was last in the shooting schedule. So yeah, we jumped on board very late in the day and had to turn it around quite quickly."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Leane |first=Rob |date=2019-08-29 |title=The VFX secrets of Amazon's The Boys |url=https://www.denofgeek.com/tv/the-vfx-secrets-of-amazon-s-the-boys/ |access-date=2023-07-10 |website=Den of Geek |language=en-US |archive-date=April 21, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220421225515/https://www.denofgeek.com/tv/the-vfx-secrets-of-amazon-s-the-boys/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

===Music===
In July 2018, it was confirmed that [[Christopher Lennertz]] would be composing the score for the television series, having previously worked with Kripke on ''[[Supernatural (American TV series)|Supernatural]]'' and ''[[Revolution (TV series)|Revolution]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Christopher Lennertz to Score Amazon's ‚ÄòThe Boys‚Äô |url=https://filmmusicreporter.com/2018/07/17/christopher-lennertz-to-score-amazons-the-boys/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180720032638/https://filmmusicreporter.com/2018/07/17/christopher-lennertz-to-score-amazons-the-boys/ |archive-date=July 20, 2018 |access-date=2024-08-02 |website=Film Music Reporter |language=en-US}}</ref> Lennertz was approached by Kripke while the former was working with Rogen for the [[adult animated]] film ''[[Sausage Party]]'', where Kripke told him that he was developing a comic book series into a television adaptation about corrupt superheroes alongside Rogen. The composer read all the comics before shooting started in order to have a better idea of how to appreach the score, which led him to "develop a different that would make it disturbing, nasty, violent, garagey, sloppy, dirty and gritty." He experimented with new instruments such as old lamps and broken amps to get distorting and grungy sounds, intending to capture the escence of a superhero world in real life where things can things can go wrong.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Carr |first=Martin |date=2019-08-01 |title=Exclusive Interview - Composer Chris Lennertz discusses The Boys |url=https://www.flickeringmyth.com/2019/08/exclusive-interview-composer-chris-lennertz-discusses-the-boys/ |access-date=2022-07-10 |website=Flickering Myth |language=en-US}}</ref> 

After writing several demos to make the score fit into the narrative of the series, Lennertz opted to develop two methods with each one aimed at the two main groups of the series which are the Boys and the Seven. The first method was the music aimed to the Boys, where Lennertz made use of guitars, drums and amplifiers as Kripke wanted to have the music of the eponymous team to be "dirt and grime of a messy garage band with the energy of British punk and that he wanted to poke fun at traditional superhero clich√©s." The second method was the music aimed to the Seven, where Lennertz combined traditional orchestra and electronic sounds that would shatter the perfect stereotypes of comic book heroes. He made the music of the team to initially start with the orchestral classical superhero music, only to have it processed by slowing the music down to make it sound more distorted and get the feeling that things are starting to go wrong, making the audience to realize that the superheroes of this universe are actually deranged and capable of betraying everyone's trust.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Goldowitz |first=Paul |date=2019-07-26 |title=Christopher Lennertz Interview {{!}} Composer of Amazon's The Boys and Netflix's Lost In Space |url=https://www.popdisciple.com/interviews/christopher-lennertz |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200216181032/https://www.popdisciple.com/interviews/christopher-lennertz |archive-date=February 16, 2020 |access-date=2024-08-02 |website=Pop Disciple |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Hannett|first=Michelle|date=August 5, 2019|title=WAMG's Conversation With Composer Christopher Lennertz On His Super-Hero Score For Amazon Prime's THE BOYS|url=http://www.wearemoviegeeks.com/2019/08/wamgs-conversation-with-composer-christopher-lennertz-on-his-super-hero-score-for-amazon-primes-the-boys/|access-date=June 11, 2021|website=We Are Movie Geeks|archive-date=June 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210611011040/http://www.wearemoviegeeks.com/2019/08/wamgs-conversation-with-composer-christopher-lennertz-on-his-super-hero-score-for-amazon-primes-the-boys/|url-status=live}}</ref> On June 17, 2019, individual posters for the members of the Seven begin to be released, with the tagline "Never Meet Your Heroes" which reflects of how the each member of them behave in the series.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Destito |first=Deanna |date=June 17, 2019 |title=The Seven are here: check out new posters from Amazon's THE BOYS |url=https://www.comicsbeat.com/posters-the-seven-the-boys/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220421031302/https://www.comicsbeat.com/posters-the-seven-the-boys/ |archive-date=April 21, 2022 |access-date=August 4, 2024 |website=[[The Beat (magazine)|The Beat]]}}</ref> The official and final trailer of the series was released on July 23, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Darwish |first=Meaghan |date=2019-07-23 |title='The Boys' Final Trailer Teases a Bitter Battle Against Bad Superheroes (VIDEO) |url=https://www.tvinsider.com/797025/the-boys-final-trailer-amazon-prime-video/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190724191617/https://www.tvinsider.com/797025/the-boys-final-trailer-amazon-prime-video/ |archive-date=July 24, 2019 |access-date=2024-08-04 |website=TV Insider |language=en-US}}</ref> Germain Lussier from ''[[Gizmodo]]'' considered that in contrast of the previous trailers which focused on showing the scope of the show, this one "weaves that in and out with the more personal story. The story of a man who loses the woman he loves in a truly horrific fashion and finds a way to get revenge."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lussier |first=Germain |date=2019-07-23 |title=If This Trailer Doesn't Make You Want to Watch The Boys, Nothing Will |url=https://gizmodo.com/if-this-trailer-doesnt-make-you-want-to-watch-the-boys-1836636537 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211120011510/https://gizmodo.com/if-this-trailer-doesnt-make-you-want-to-watch-the-boys-1836636537 |archive-date=November 20, 2021 |access-date=2024-08-04 |website=[[Gizmodo]] |language=en-US}}</ref> Christine Fernando from ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'' commented that while the trailer started showing of how we see the superheroes, it proceed to show us that it was only a facade and that in reality the superheroes are " narcissistic and sociopathic assholes."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fernando |first=Christine |date=July 23, 2019 |title=Watch Karl Urban in the Bloody Final Trailer for The Boys |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/tv/the-boys/watch-karl-urban-in-the-bloody-new-trailer-for-the |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201125002011/https://www.pastemagazine.com/tv/the-boys/watch-karl-urban-in-the-bloody-new-trailer-for-the/ |archive-date=November 25, 2020 |access-date=2024-08-04 |website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |language=en-US}}</ref>

==Release==
The first season premiered on [[Amazon Prime Video]] on July 26, 2019, consisting of eight episodes.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=April 17, 2019|title='The Boys' Trailer: First Look At Amazon's Superhero Drama Series|url=https://deadline.com/video/the-boys-trailer-amazon-superhero-drama-series-garth-ennis-darick-robertson-eric-kripke/|access-date=June 13, 2021|website=[[Deadline Hollywood|Deadline]]|archive-date=November 14, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221114140250/https://deadline.com/video/the-boys-trailer-amazon-superhero-drama-series-garth-ennis-darick-robertson-eric-kripke/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Malone|first=Michael|date=April 17, 2019|title=Superhero Series 'The Boys' Starts on Amazon July 26|url=https://www.nexttv.com/news/superhero-series-the-boys-starts-on-amazon-july-26|access-date=June 13, 2021|website=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|archive-date=June 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210613054825/https://www.nexttv.com/news/superhero-series-the-boys-starts-on-amazon-july-26|url-status=live}}</ref>  All the eight episodes which complement the whole season were released the same date of its premiere.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gemmill |first=Allie |last2=Bloom |first2=Mike |date=2021-05-09 |title='The Boys' Season 1 release date, trailer, cast, plot, renewal, and more |url=https://www.inverse.com/entertainment/55035-the-boys-release-date-trailer-cast-plot-spoilers-for-the-amazon-show |access-date=2023-12-24 |website=[[Inverse (website)|Inverse]] |language=en |archive-date=December 2, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231202162436/https://www.inverse.com/entertainment/55035-the-boys-release-date-trailer-cast-plot-spoilers-for-the-amazon-show |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== Home media ===
The first season of ''The Boys'' was released on [[Blu-ray]] as part of a six-disc box set of the first two seasons by [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment]] on May 31, 2022. Special features included deleted scenes and a blooper reel.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Zogbi |first=Emily |date=2022-04-05 |title=The Boys Seasons 1 and 2 Get Blu-ray Release With Deleted and Extended Scenes |url=https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-seasons-1-2-blu-ray-amazon-sony/ |access-date=2023-12-31 |website=[[Comic Book Resources]] |language=en |archive-date=June 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220617222152/https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-seasons-1-2-blu-ray-amazon-sony/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

==Reception==
===Critical response===
On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the first season holds an approval rating of 85% based on 106 reviews, with an average rating of 7.6/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "Though viewers' mileage may vary, ''The Boys''{{'}} violent delights and willingness to engage in heavy, relevant themes are sure to please those looking for a new group of antiheroes to root for."<ref>{{cite web |title=The Boys: Season 1 (2019) |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the_boys_2019/s01 |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |access-date=August 17, 2020 |archive-date=April 24, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210424042058/https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the_boys_2019/s01 |url-status=live }}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the season has a weighted average score of 74 out of 100, based on reviews from 19 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-boys/season-1 |title=The Boys: Season 1 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |access-date=January 5, 2020 |archive-date=August 15, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200815002007/https://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-boys/season-1 |url-status=live }}</ref>

Christopher Lawrence of the ''[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]'' called ''The Boys'' "irreverent, and deliciously cynical. The series follows the greed and corruption behind the superhero industrial complex."<ref>{{cite web |date=July 24, 2019 |first=Christopher |last=Lawrence |title=New series 'The Boys,' 'Pennyworth' showcase comic books' versatility |url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/entertainment-columns/christopher-lawrence/new-series-the-boys-pennyworth-showcase-comic-books-versatility-1810241/ |website=Las Vegas Review-Journal |access-date=March 24, 2022 |archive-date=July 16, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220716112337/https://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/entertainment-columns/christopher-lawrence/new-series-the-boys-pennyworth-showcase-comic-books-versatility-1810241/ |url-status=live }}</ref> For a review at ''[[The Ringer (website)|The Ringer]]'', Alison Herman considered that the series offered not only a more realistic over how the heroes would be portrayed in real life, but also over the companies have handled those franchises and the real life allegories that are portrayed in real life, commenting that thanks to the series "it's possible to get a kick out of laser beams and fight scenes while also being worn out by their excesses‚Äînot just the naivete, but the profiteering, the blandness, the micromanaged narratives passed off as expression. One show can't turn the tides of change, but at least it can commiserate."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Herman |first=Alison |date=2019-09-06 |title=As Disney+ Looms, ‚ÄòThe Boys‚Äô Is Sweet Relief |url=https://www.theringer.com/tv/2019/9/6/20850067/the-boys-amazon-superheroes-disney-plus-marvel |access-date=2023-12-19 |website=[[The Ringer (website)|The Ringer]] |language=en |archive-date=December 19, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231219203904/https://www.theringer.com/tv/2019/9/6/20850067/the-boys-amazon-superheroes-disney-plus-marvel |url-status=live }}</ref> Mel Campbell of Screen Hub deemed the show as "shockingly violent and pointedly political, this Amazon series is an ironic but refreshing antidote to supe franchising. ... The Boys throws our ugly cultural obsessions back in our faces."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Campbell|first=Mel|date=August 23, 2019|title=TV Review: The Boys splatter-punches superheroes|url=https://www.screenhub.com.au/news-article/reviews/television/mel-campbell/tv-review-the-boys-splatter-punches-superheroes-258438|access-date=June 8, 2021|website=Screenhub Australia|archive-date=June 8, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210608193848/https://www.screenhub.com.au/news-article/reviews/television/mel-campbell/tv-review-the-boys-splatter-punches-superheroes-258438|url-status=live}}</ref> Daniel Fienberg from [[The Hollywood Reporter|''Hollywood Reporter'']] in a positive response praised it and stated, "I'll have to check in again on ''The Boys'' after a few more episodes to get a sense of whether or not the encroaching cynicism topples what I find initially promising here."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Fienberg|first=Daniel|date=April 29, 2019|title='The Boys': TV Review {{!}} Tribeca 2019|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/tv/tv-reviews/boys-review-1205773/|access-date=June 9, 2021|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|archive-date=June 9, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210609042949/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/tv/tv-reviews/boys-review-1205773/|url-status=live}}</ref> Graeme Virtue from ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave the series four of five stars considered that "while both have an appealing innocence, it is Moriarty's maltreated but undaunted Starlight who, appropriately, feels like she is preventing the whole thing from collapsing into darkness."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Virtue|first=Graeme|date=July 26, 2019|title=The Boys review ‚Äì sick of superheroes? Here's the remedy|url=http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2019/jul/26/the-boys-review-sick-of-superheroes-heres-the-remedy|access-date=June 9, 2021|website=[[The Guardian]]|archive-date=June 9, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210609042952/https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2019/jul/26/the-boys-review-sick-of-superheroes-heres-the-remedy|url-status=live}}</ref> Kristy Puchko at ''[[IGN]]'' gives the first episode a score of 7.2/10 and appreciates how the story comes from the comics but with clever changes. Puchko praises the cast, particularly "Moriarty brings a nuance to her performance that refuses to let Starlight feel like a two-dimensional damsel. She's not na√Øve. She's hopeful. And she's a fighter. ''The Boys'' makes all of that clear in short order." She concludes: "''The Boys'' could still be a thrilling ride as it subverts the expectations of the family-friendly genre, with dark twists and unapologetically graphic scenes of sex and violence. The premiere ep has a lot of heavy lifting to do in exposition, yet Kripke works in some stunner moments, jolts of fun, and stellar action sequences."<ref>{{cite web |date=June 6, 2019 |first1=Kristy |last1=Puchko |title=Amazon's The Boys: Series Premiere Review |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2019/05/01/amazons-the-boys-series-premiere-review |website=IGN Movies |publisher=[[IGN]] |access-date=March 24, 2022 |archive-date=June 15, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220615175314/https://www.ign.com/articles/2019/05/01/amazons-the-boys-series-premiere-review |url-status=live }}</ref> James McMahon from the ''[[NME]]'' lauded the series for its social commentary and themes, commenting that it arrived at the perfect time and that power can corrupt an individual, making examples with celebrities such as [[Harvey Weinstein]], [[Richard Branson]] and [[Michael Jackson]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=McMahon |first=James |date=2019-08-05 |title=Amazon Prime's The Boys review: zeitgeisty adaptation of comic book for an era with no more heroes |url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/2535252-2535252 |access-date=2023-12-19 |website=[[NME]] |language=en-GB |archive-date=December 19, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231219203904/https://www.nme.com/reviews/2535252-2535252 |url-status=live }}</ref>

Liz Shannon Miller of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' deemed that "[[Karl Urban]] proves to be a thoroughly committed performer as Billy Butcher, whose dedication to taking down "supes" of course has a personal edge, but then again, when you see what men like the blatantly fake and evil Homelander ([[Antony Starr]]) are getting up to it makes sense that he's devoted his life to taking down the cause."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Miller |first=Liz Shannon |title=It's fun playing with The Boys‚Äîtoo bad they don't have anything to say |url=https://tv.avclub.com/it-s-fun-playing-with-the-boys-too-bad-they-don-t-have-1836637109 |access-date=July 29, 2019 |website=TV Club |date=July 26, 2019 |archive-date=July 28, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190728013938/https://tv.avclub.com/it-s-fun-playing-with-the-boys-too-bad-they-don-t-have-1836637109 |url-status=live }}</ref> Matthew Dessem from [[Slate (magazine)|''Slate'']] called ''The Boys'' "an expert deconstruction of superhero stories, with an appropriately wintery view of institutional power, be it corporate, governmental, religious, or caped."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dessem |first=Matthew |date=August 15, 2019 |title=Amazon's Superhero Satire The Boys Is Wonderfully Tasteless and Occasionally Timely |url=https://slate.com/culture/2019/08/the-boys-amazon-series-comic-book-adaptation-trump-marvel.html |access-date=June 8, 2021 |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |archive-date=June 8, 2021 The cast is fine, particularly Shue, who is icily effective; Quaid, whose neurotic but brave fumblings are endearing; and Urban, who is Hughie's gonzo guide. But the real star of 'The Boys' is the situation itself."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gilbert |first=Matthew |date=July 24, 2019 |title=In 'The Boys,' there's no saving these narcissistic superheroes - The Boston Globe |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/television/2019/07/24/the-boys-there-saving-these-narcissistic-superheroes/SfPVEV6erHppP91ZQMkkrL/story.html |access-date=June 8, 2021 |website=[[The Boston Globe]] |archive-date=May 21, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210521004954/https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/television/2019/07/24/the-boys-there-saving-these-narcissistic-superheroes/SfPVEV6erHppP91ZQMkkrL/story.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Jeffrey Parking gave a positive review to the series for ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'', praising the portrayal of superheroes in a more flawed and human way and comparing them with their original counterparts. Ben Travers from ''[[IndieWire]]'' gave the show a "B" and said that "given the top-notch special effects and sharp writing at the core of 'The Boys,' there are still loads of potential within this well-realized universe. Let's just hope this ending really did save the cat."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Travers |first=Ben |date=2019-07-27 |title='The Boys' Review: Season 1's Surprise Ending Swoops in to Save Amazon's Superhero Story ‚Äî Spoilers |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/the-boys-spoilers-review-season-1-ending-amazon-1202161314/ |access-date=2022-04-21 |website=[[IndieWire]] |archive-date=December 4, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211204160945/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/the-boys-spoilers-review-season-1-ending-amazon-1202161314/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Mike Hale from ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised the series for its departure from the traditional superhero shows including the ones produced by [[Netflix]] stating, "''The Boys'', meanwhile, is offering the kind of smart, easygoing pleasure that most of the Marvel Netflix shows, its closest analogues, didn't quite reach."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hale |first=Mike |date=2019-07-26 |title=Review: 'The Boys' Deconstructs the Superhero, With a Light Touch |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/26/arts/television/review-the-boys-amazon-prime.html |access-date=2022-04-21 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=November 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20191126214728/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/26/arts/television/review-the-boys-amazon-prime.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Daniel D'Addario from [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] recognized the first episode for the potential, though criticized its tone and writing, "All viewers at Tribeca had to go on was a first episode, and 'The Boys' could become any number of things as it rolls on. But the tone it struck in its first outing was a dully familiar one ‚Äî the sense that to transgress, alone, is enough. If this show is to actually satirize the wide-open target of superhero entertainments, it'll need to find a second gear, and quickly."<ref>{{Cite web |last=D'Addario |first=Daniel |date=2019-04-30 |title=TV Review: 'The Boys' |url=https://variety.com/2019/tv/reviews/amazon-the-boys-1203199336/ |access-date=2022-04-21 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |archive-date=April 21, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220421042833/https://variety.com/2019/tv/reviews/amazon-the-boys-1203199336/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Vinnie Mancuso from [[Collider (website)|''Collider'']] appreciated the show social commentary themes and scoring the entire season 5 out of 5 stars and said, "Like [[Alan Moore]]'s ''[[Watchmen]]'' in the late-80s, ''The Boys'' TV series has the chance to be the superhero deconstruction of our time. Less a peek behind the curtain, and more a seedy glimpse behind the social media likes and box office numbers, a story that manages to be heartbreakingly relevant while still finding time to have Karl Urban kill a room full of goons with a super-powered baby."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mancuso |first=Vinnie |date=July 26, 2019 |title=The Boys Review: Amazon's Superhero Satire Is Watchmen for a New Age |url=https://collider.com/the-boys-review-amazon/ |access-date=April 21, 2022 |website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |archive-date=April 21, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220421042833/https://collider.com/the-boys-review-amazon/ |url-status=live }}</ref> A review at ''[[Now (newspaper)|Now]]'' by Normal Wilner, praise was given to the chemistry between Quaid and Moriarty and that their characters is what lead the series to its potential. However, it was considered that the character of Butcher fails to capture the charisma of the other Urban's performances and deemed that his lines were repetitive in every episode, while Homelander's storyline in the season and character in general was disturbing and creepy.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Willner |first=Norman |date=July 29, 2019 |title=TV review: Amazon's The Boys is almost a great show |url=https://nowtoronto.com/movies/the-boys-amazon-prime-video/ |access-date=2023-12-20 |website=[[Now (newspaper)|Now]] |language=en-US |archive-date=December 20, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231220053351/https://nowtoronto.com/movies/the-boys-amazon-prime-video/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Shana O'Neil for ''[[The Verge]]'' commented on the series, "filled with blasphemy, guts, sex, and heartfelt emotion, The Boys is going to alienate some viewers. It's deliberately pushing boundaries. It's crass, it's bloody, it's brutal, and it's got a raunchy sense of humor. But it's a hell of a lot of fun. And for viewers who love a little anarchy and bedlam in their superhero drama, it hits all the right notes. "<ref>{{Cite web |last=O'Neil |first=Shana |date=2019-07-24 |title=The Boys is a bloody manic mayhem dream show |url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/7/24/20707596/the-boys-review-tv-amazon-prime-video-karl-urban-garth-ennis-elisabeth-shue-jack-quaid-erin-moriarty |access-date=2023-12-20 |website=[[The Verge]] |language=en |archive-date=December 20, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231220063230/https://www.theverge.com/2019/7/24/20707596/the-boys-review-tv-amazon-prime-video-karl-urban-garth-ennis-elisabeth-shue-jack-quaid-erin-moriarty |url-status=live }}</ref>

|date=2019-10-25 |title=Nielsen to begin tracking Amazon Prime viewership |url=https://showsnob.com/2019/10/25/nielsen-ratings-amazon-prime-viewership/ |access-date=2023-12-18 |website=[[Fansided]] |language=en-US |archive-date=December 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231218231952/https://showsnob.com/2019/10/25/nielsen-ratings-amazon-prime-viewership/ |url-status=live |url=https://gritdaily.com/nielsen-is-now-tracking-amazon-prime-video-ratings/ |access-date=2023-12-18 |website=Grit Daily News |language=en-US |archive-date=December 18, 2023 attracted over 8{{nbsp}}million of viewers on Prime Video during the first ten days of release, having the average audience size of the series being at 4.1 million with an average of 6 million having watched the episode's premiere.<ref>{{cite web |date=October 21, 2019 |last=Hayes |first=Dade |title=Amazon Prime Viewing Added To Nielsen, Which Reveals ''The Boys'' Numbers 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201009160209/https://deadline.com/2019/10/amazon-prime-viewing-added-to-nielsen-which-reveals-the-boys-numbers-1202765075/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=James|first=Jessica|date=October 21, 2019|title=The Boys Attracted More Than 4 Million Viewers In 10 Days|url=https://wegotthiscovered.com/tv/boys-attracted-4-million-viewers-10-days/|access-date=June 13, 2021|website=We Got This Covered|language=en-US|archive-date=June 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210613054853/https://wegotthiscovered.com/tv/boys-attracted-4-million-viewers-10-days/|url-status=live}}</ref> It became Prime Video's most watched series with 39% of the audience being in the age range of 35‚Äì49.<ref>{{Cite web |last=McNulty |first=Matthew |date=2019-10-22 |title=Amazon's 'The Boys' racks up big viewership - or did it? |url=https://www.foxbusiness.com/media/amazons-the-boys-racks-up-big-viewership-or-did-it |access-date=2023-12-18 |website=[[Fox Business]] |language=en-US |archive-date=December 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231218225653/https://www.foxbusiness.com/media/amazons-the-boys-racks-up-big-viewership-or-did-it |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Maas |access-date=2023-12-18 |website=[[TheWrap]] |language=en-US |archive-date=December 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231218234236/https://www.thewrap.com/nielsen-amazon-prime-video-ratings-the-boys-viewers/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The head of Amazon Studios Jennifer Salme
